0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Natalizumab (Tysabri(R)) is available only through the TOUCH(R) Prescribing Program to prescribers, infusion centers, and pharmacies associated with infusion centers registered through the program. Additionally, Tysabri(R) can only be prescribed to patients who are enrolled in and meet all the requirements of the program. Contact the TOUCH(R) Prescribing Program at 1-800-456-2255 for details and enrollment.
  • Crohn's disease (Moderate to Severe): 300 mg IV over 1 hour, repeat every 4 weeks; discontinue therapy for lack of therapeutic benefits by 12 weeks after initiation of therapy
  • Multiple sclerosis, relapsing forms of the disease: 300 mg IV infused over 1 hour, given at 4-week intervals

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Crohn's disease (Moderate to Severe)
  • Multiple sclerosis, relapsing forms of the disease

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Intravenous (Solution)
Natalizumab increases the risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), an opportunistic viral infection of the brain that usually leads to death or severe disability. Risk factors for PML include therapy duration, prior immunosuppressant use, and presence of anti-JC virus antibodies. Because of the risk of PML, natalizumab is available only through a restricted program under a Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy (REMS) called the TOUCH(R) Prescribing Program. Monitor patients for any new sign or symptom that may be suggestive of PML and interrupt therapy at the first sign or symptom suggestive of PML. For diagnosis, a gadolinium-enhanced MRI scan of the brain and, if indicated, cerebrospinal fluid analysis for JC viral DNA are recommended.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Hypersensitivity to natalizumab or any component of the product
  • History of or active progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, potentially fatal, has been reported, with an increased risk with prolonged use, prior immunosuppressant use, and in anti-JC virus antibody positive patients; monitoring recommended and interrupt therapy at first sign or symptom
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Clinically significant hepatotoxicity, including acute liver failure requiring transplant, has been reported; discontinue use with laboratory or clinical evidence of liver injury
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Hypersensitivity reactions, sometimes serious (eg, anaphylaxis), have been reported, usually within 2 hours after starting infusion and with an increased risk in patients recommencing therapy after dose interruption or with persistent antibodies; permanently discontinue use if occurs
  • -- Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome has been reported several days to weeks after plasma exchange in patients who discontinue therapy due to progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy; monitoring recommended
  • -- Serious infections have been reported, especially with concomitant corticosteroids or immunosuppressants
  • -- Use not recommended in patients immunocompromised from existing systemic medical condition; increased risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy or other serious infection
  • -- Do not perform anti-JC virus antibody testing for at least 2 weeks after plasma infusion due to removal of antibodies from serum
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Herpes encephalitis and meningitis, including fatalities, have been reported in multiple sclerosis patients; monitoring recommended and discontinue use if occurs
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Concomitant use of antineoplastic, immunosuppressant, or immunomodulator therapy not recommended
  • -- Concomitant use of chronic corticosteroids in patients with Crohn disease; withdraw steroids as soon as therapeutic benefit occurs and discontinue natalizumab if systemic corticosteroid use continues beyond 6 months

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash (multiple sclerosis, 12%; Crohn disease, 6%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal discomfort (11%), Diarrhea (10%), Gastroenteritis (11%), Nausea (17%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (multiple sclerosis, 19%; Crohn disease, 8%), Pain in limb (16%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (32% to 38%)
  • Psychiatric:Depression (19%)
  • Renal:Urinary tract infectious disease (multiple sclerosis, 21%; Crohn disease, 3%)
  • Respiratory:Lower respiratory tract infection (17%), Upper respiratory infection (22%)
  • Other:Fatigue (multiple sclerosis, 27%; Crohn disease, 10%)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Adhesion of abdominal wall (0.3%), Appendicitis (0.8%), Bowel obstruction
  • Hematologic:Anemia
  • Hepatic:Cholelithiasis (0.3% to 1%), Hepatotoxicity
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (0.8%), Hypersensitivity reaction, Immune reconstitution syndrome
  • Neurologic:Herpes virus infection of the central nervous system, Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (0.1% to 0.2%)
  • Psychiatric:Suicidal thoughts (0.6%)
  • Respiratory:Pneumonia (0.6%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Natalizumab, a recombinant humanized IgG4-kappa monoclonal antibody, prevents transmigration of leukocytes across the endothelium into the inflamed parenchymal tissue by binding to the alpha-4-subunit of alpha-4-beta-1 and alpha-4-beta-7 integrins on the surface of all leukocytes (except neutrophils) and inhibits the alpha 4-mediated adhesion of leukocytes to their counter-receptors. It blocks the molecular interaction of alpha 4 beta 1-integrin with vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1) on activated vascular endothelial cells, mucosal addressin cell adhesion molecule-1 (MAdCAM-1) on vascular endothelial gastrointestinal cells, and with connecting segment-1 (CS-1). In vivo, natalizumab may also inhibit the interaction of alpha-4 integrin antibodies and ligands extracellularly and on parenchymal cells, inhibiting continued recruitment and inflammatory activity of activated immune cells.

1.title: Distribution
1.mono:
• Vd, Crohn disease: 5.2 L
  • Vd, Multiple sclerosis: 5.7 L (300 mg); approximately 90 mL/kg (1 and 3 mg/kg)

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Total body, Crohn disease: 22 mL/hr
  • Total body, multiple sclerosis: 16 mL/hr (300 mg); 0.3 mL/hr/kg (1 mg/kg); 0.6 mL/hr/kg (3 mg/kg)

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• approximately 90 to 170 hours
  • Crohn disease: 10 days
  • Multiple sclerosis: 11 +/- 4 days

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    give by IV infusion only; do not give IV push or IV bolus
  • Intravenous
    • dilute contents of single-use vial in 100 mL NS; do not use other diluents or mix with other drugs; gently invert to mix; do not shake
    • if not infused immediately, refrigerate at 2 to 8 degrees and use within 8 hours; allow to come to room temperature prior to infusion.
    • infuse over 1 hour (approximately 5 mg/min)
    • do not inject any other drugs via side ports during infusion
    • flush line with NS after the infusion is complete and observe patient for 1 hour after infusion for hypersensitivity

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• evaluate, as required by the TOUCH (R) Prescribing Program, 3 and 6 months after the first infusion, every 6 months during therapy, and for at least 6 months after discontinuation
  • Crohn's disease: decrease in the Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI) score is indicative of efficacy
  • multiple sclerosis: longer time to onset of sustained increase in disability and reduction in annualized relapse rate is indicative of efficacy
  • anti-JC virus antibodies; prior to treatment or during treatment if status is unknown; retest periodically if initial result negative; wait at least 2 weeks after plasma exchange to perform test
  • serum antibodies to natalizumab in select patients, particularly if suspected; repeat 3 months after initial positive result to confirm; consider antibody testing in patients who wish to recommence therapy following a dose interruption
  • development of infection
  • MRI scan in patients with multiple sclerosis prior to initiating therapy; baseline MRI may also be helpful in patients with Crohn's Disease
  • signs/symptoms of hypersensitivity during the infusion and for 1 hour after infusion
  • signs/symptoms of meningitis and encephalitis
  • signs/symptoms suggestive of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy; during treatment and for 6 months following discontinuation

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Side effects may include depression, rash, arthralgia, diarrhea, nausea, headache, pain in extremity, abdominal discomfort, and fatigue.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (progressive weakness on 1 side of the body, clumsiness of limbs, disturbance of vision, changes in thinking, memory, or orientation leading to confusion and personality changes) during treatment and for at least 6 months following discontinuation.
  • Advise patient tor report signs/symptoms of encephalitis or meningitis (eg, fever, headache, confusion).
  • Patient should report signs/symptoms of hepatotoxicity (fatigue, anorexia, right upper abdominal discomfort, dark urine, or jaundice).
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of infection.
